title: Is academia in general not a place for nice people? - Quora

response.answer_text: At least in engineering fields (which is what I’m most familiar with), academia is filled with people who decided to take a high-stress, high-effort, job in which they will make only a fraction of what they could easily make in industry. Why did they decide to do that? For most, it’s because they care about improving the world through their research and/or teaching more than they value making money. That sounds like at least a pretty good start toward being nice…. Are there some people in academia who aren’t nice? Of course. People are people. How many are not nice? Well, it depends a lot on the local culture. In my area at the University of Kentucky, I don’t think we currently have any faculty who aren’t at least reasonably nice (and that culture is part of why I’m here). On the other hand, from what I’ve seen elsewhere, it’s pretty common to have a single-digit percentage of faculty be not very nice in ways ranging from being too focused on their personal prestige to simply not caring about the students they are supposed to be teaching. I think education and having a career tend to make it easier to be nice; they give a sense of purpose and stability that make being kind to others not feel like it is at your expense. In seven years of foster parenting, I learned that the fraction of the general population who are un-nice enough to abuse their kids is frighteningly higher than I had ever imagined… but I also saw patterns in the abuse. The abuser usually had neither a sense of purpose nor stability, and often had been abused themselves — which usually meant they had no positive role models. In some sense, one could say that the whole point of academia is to sow the seeds of purpose and stability that will allow niceness to blossom.

Academia is very competitive, and most competitive places are terrible spots for nice people.  If you want to be a professor at a top school you can't afford to take any actions that would hurt your career, like Quitting grad school to care for your aging parentsOnly applying to schools close to home so you can be close to your friends and familyTaking nights and weekends off to pursue hobbies and nurture relationshipsYou might by accident have good relationships, if your current job makes it convenient for you to see people.  And you can certainly have good collaborations, provided they're in your self-interest.  But if you want to be successful, you need to choose yourself over others every time. If you succeed in this, you get absolute power over a bunch of grad students, and you quickly realize you can treat them like shit while suffering almost no consequences.  Since many professors are selfish, utility-maximizing people to begin with, being kind to grad students is very low on their priority list, and that's why many people are miserable in PhD programs.
